alert.note: Alert for Guam (Guam) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued September 24 at 5:41AM ChST by NWS Guam
info.description: ...LOCALLY HEAVY RAINFALL AND NEAR GALE-FORCE GUSTS POSSIBLE DUE TO PASSING TROPICAL DISTURBANCE THROUGH MONDAY... A tropical disturbance, known as Invest 96W, is located to the southeast of the Marianas and slowly moving west, expected to pass just south of Guam in the next few days. 96W and a corresponding surface trough over the area are expected to bring numerous locally heavy showers and isolated thunderstorms Sunday and Sunday night. Rainfall: Training cells can bring rain amounts between 2 and 4 inches, with locally heavier amounts in excess of 4 to 6 inches possible as indicated by the GFS ensemble probability trends. While soil moisture has been decreasing since the last major rain event, some areas may continue to be under risk of additional rainfall becoming run-off quickly. Localized flooding is possible in low-lying and poor drainage areas. If living near streams and rivers, prepare to move items away from stream and river banks. Make sure storm drains nearby are not clogged, especially in low-lying areas. Winds: East winds of 10 to 15 mph are expected to shift to the southwest tonight, becoming 15 to 25 mph after midnight, with occasional gusts to 35 mph on Sunday. Winds will diminish slightly Sunday night, before becoming more southerly and moderate starting Monday. Seas: Combined seas of around 4 feet are expected to quickly increase to between 5 and 8 feet Saturday night into Sunday as winds shift and increase. The seas will start to subside quickly starting Monday. Folks in the Marianas should keep up-to-date with the latest statements and advisories from the National Weather Service and your local emergency management offices. Forecast products issued by the National Weather Service are posted on the WFO Guam web page at www.weather.gov/gum.
